subject: Re: How to run same testcase with 20 different arg-values to test diff. results
msgSnippet: but but but... public void testMax() { testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue); } public void testMin() { testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue,
messageBody:
but but but...

public void testMax() {
testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
}

public void testMin() {
testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
}

.
.
.

would still work, and is more concise than creating 200 new test
classes with different setUp/tearDown methods. what's so hated about
grouping them all in the same method, though? sure you're running
multiple tests in one test method, but it is still easy to track
specific problems down since you get the stack trace.

will



-- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> >So said Andrew McDonagh on 2003-07-23 --------------------
> >
> >Also what about....
> >
> >
> >taking original test case extract the test case code into a private
method,
> >to which the params are passed. Then in the original test case
method, we
> >simply call the private one n times with different param values.
> >
> >Original code:
> >
> >public void testIntegers() {
> >
> > assertEquals(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
> > assertEquals(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
> >}
> >
> >
> >would then become...
> >
> >
> >public void testIntegers() {
> > testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
> > testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
> > testTwoIntegers(new Integer(232), new Integer(232));
> > ...
> >}
> >
> >
> >private void testTwoIntegers(Integer expected, Integer actual) {
> > // Setup could even be called from here if needed!
> >
> > assertEquals(expected, actual);
> >
> > // If setup is called from here, then you'd no doubt want to cal
> >tearDown
> >as well
> >}
>
> Problem: that's just one (JUnit) test, when really it's three
(logical) tests.
>
>
